metadata.title: Sustainability in Blockchain: A Systematic Literature Review on Scalability and Power Consumption Issues
metadata.author: Hani Alshahrani, Noman Islam, Darakhshan Syed, Adel Sulaiman, Mana Saleh Al Reshan, Khairan Rajab, Asadullah Shaikh, Jaweed Shuja-Uddin and Aadar Soomro
metadata.subject: Blockchain is a peer-to-peer trustless network that keeps records of digital assets without any central authority. With the passage of time, the sustainability issue of blockchain is rising. This paper discusses two major sustainability issues of blockchain: power consumption and scalability. It discusses the challenge of power consumption by analyzing various approaches to estimating power consumption in the literature. A case study of bitcoin is presented for this purpose. The study presents a review of the growing energy consumption of bitcoin along with a solution for immersion cooling in blockchain mining. The second challenge addressed in this research is scalability. With the increase in network size, scalability issues are also increasing as the number of transactions per second is decreasing. In other words, blockchain is observing low throughput with its increase in size. The paper discusses research studies and techniques proposed in the literature. The paper then investigates how to scale blockchain for better performance.
metadata.keywords: blockchain; bitcoin; scalability; power consumption; immersion cooling

In other cases, they can be managed by a third-party [PAGE 1] organization. In the case of a digital payment or transfer between two businesses, a bank or [PAGE 1] credit card vendor, for example, functions as a third party. All successful transactions are [PAGE 1] paid for by the client ﬁrms. A third-party ﬁrm handles and manages practically all of the [PAGE 1] interaction in the online process in this one-size-ﬁts-all approach. This approach obviously [PAGE 1] requires the use of a third party to ensure the transaction’s security. A blockchain, on the [PAGE 1] other hand, is a widely dispersed and securely managed peer-to-peer network where no [PAGE 1] third party is necessary to handle information and trust between network users.
